text: I know it was kind of a niche game, but I loved Blue Dragon so much.  Partly it was the Toriyama's art style, but it was also so charming.  I especially loved the snowy areas, they were so comfy.  I even watched some of the anime.  Always wanted to play the dev's other RPG, Last Odyssey, but never got a chance.  Please for the love of god I want a remake of that game.

text:
I disagree, while beautifully animated, the Ghibli movies are mostly simple children's tale that try to amaze you with it's art direction instead of the story it's trying to tell. The one exception is Princess Mononoke which pulls no punches and is probably Miyazaki's best work.

While decreasing in number because of the current "moe" cute trend, there's still a lot of anime out there that uses other forms of appeal than the ones you've listed above that can arguably deliver a different yet satisfying/entertaining experience compared with other styles of animation.
author: The Maestro

text:
@DocThor Perhaps that's the origin of the term 'anime,' but like with most words, it slowly evolved to mean something more specific by its users (i.e. 'porc' for the food, 'pig' for the animal). It's a mix of the art style, storytelling style, the musical style, and mostly, the experience of the viewer is unique compared to other styles of animation; there is an unexplainable difference between anime and Disney's Atlantis, for example.

It's like 'super hero cartoons.' You can say that Dragon Ball is about super heroes as well, but you wouldn't call it a 'super hero cartoon.' It does not fit the description, even though, fundamentally, they're all stories about super-powered humans/humanoids. You wouldn't call a Batman cartoon an 'anime' either, even if it was animated by the Japanese in Japan. So clearly, there is definition for 'anime' that is beyond the 'Japanese animation,' but it's more instinctive than rational, in my opinion.
author: Armoterra

text:
See you're not really describing anime, so much as you are describing what Western anime fan art looks like. That's not to say there aren't tons anime that fit your description, there are, but it's pretty disingenuous to say it's representative of all anime. It's like saying that all American-made movies are idiotic, brainless pieces of military endorsing because of Michael Bay movies, there's a ton of really interesting, really smart stuff if you're willing to take the time out to look for it. 

I'd recommend you check out some stuff by a guy named Mamoru Hosoda, if you like Miyazaki/Studio Ghibli you'd probably like him a whole lot.
